The Epic Continues…

Last week it was 34 years since the original launch of Mathematica and what‚Äôs now the Wolfram Language. And through all those years we‚Äôve energetically continued building further and further, adding ever more capabilities, and steadily extending the domain of the computational paradigm.

In recent years we‚Äôve established something of a rhythm, delivering the fruits of our development efforts roughly twice a year. We released Version 13.0 on December 13, 2021. And now, roughly six months later, we‚Äôre releasing Version 13.1. As usual, even though it‚Äôs a ‚Äú.1‚Äù release, it‚Äôs got a lot of new (and updated) functionality, some of which we‚Äôve worked on for many years but finally now brought to fruition.

For me it‚Äôs always exciting to see what we manage to deliver in each new version. And in Version 13.1 we have 90 completely new functions‚Äîas well as 203 existing functions with substantial updates. And beyond what appears in specific functions, there‚Äôs also major new functionality in Version 13.1 in areas like user interfaces and the compiler.

The Wolfram Language as it exists today encompasses a vast range of functionality. But its great power comes not just from what it contains, but also from how coherently everything in it fits together. And for nearly 36 years I‚Äôve taken it as a personal responsibility to ensure that that coherence is maintained. It‚Äôs taken both great focus and lots of deep intellectual work. But as I experience them every day in my use of the Wolfram Language, I‚Äôm proud of the results.

And for the past four years I‚Äôve been sharing the ‚Äúbehind the scenes‚Äù of how it‚Äôs achieved‚Äîby livestreaming our Wolfram Language design review meetings. It‚Äôs an unprecedented level of openness‚Äîand engagement with the community. In designing Version 13.1 we‚Äôve done 90 livestreams‚Äîlasting more than 96 hours. And in opening up our process we‚Äôre providing visibility not only into what was built for Version 13.1, but also of why it was built, and how decisions about it were made.

But, OK, so what finally is in Version 13.1? Let‚Äôs talk about some highlights….

Ever since Version 1.0 we‚Äôve had While[test,body] which repeatedly evaluates body while test is True. But if test isn‚Äôt True even at first, While won‚Äôt ever evaluate body. So if test isn‚Äôt True at first, Until will still evaluate body once, in effect only looking at the test after it‚Äôs evaluated the body.

Emojis! And More Multilingual Support


What is a character? Back when Version 1.0 was released, characters were represented as 8-bit objects: usually ASCII, but you could pick another ‚Äúcharacter encoding‚Äù (hence the ChararacterEncoding option) if you wanted. Then in the early 1990s came Unicode‚Äîwhich we were one of the very first companies to support. Now ‚Äúcharacters‚Äù could be 16-bit constructs, with nearly 65,536 possible ‚Äúglyphs‚Äù allocated across different languages and uses (including some mathematical symbols that we introduced). Back in the early 1990s Unicode was a newfangled thing, that operating systems didn‚Äôt yet have built-in support for. But we were betting on Unicode, and so we built our own infrastructure for handling it.


Thirty years later Unicode is indeed the universal standard for representing character-like things. But somewhere along the way, it turned out the world needed more than 16 bits‚Äô worth of character-like things. At first it was about supporting variants and historical writing systems (think: cuneiform or Linear B). But then came emoji. And it became clear that‚Äîyes, arguably in a return to the Egyptian hieroglyph style of communication‚Äîthere was an almost infinite number of possible pictorial emoji that could be made, each of them being encoded as their own Unicode code point. 


It‚Äôs been a slow expansion. Original 16-bit Unicode is ‚Äúplane 0‚Äù. Now there are up to 16 additional planes. Not quite 32-bit characters, but given the way computers work, the approach now is to allow characters to be represented by 32-bit objects. It‚Äôs far from trivial to do that uniformly and efficiently. And for us it‚Äôs been a long process to upgrade everything in our system‚Äîfrom string manipulation to notebook rendering‚Äîto handle full 32-bit characters. And that‚Äôs finally been achieved in Version 13.1.


But that‚Äôs far from all. In English we‚Äôre pretty much used to being able to treat text as a sequence of letters and other characters, with each character being separate. Things get a bit more complicated when you start to worry about diphthongs like √¶. But if there are fairly few of these, it works to just introduce them as individual ‚ÄúUnicode characters‚Äù with their own code point. But there are plenty of languages‚Äîlike Hindi or Khmer‚Äîwhere what appears in text like an individual character is really a composite of letter-like constructs, diacritical marks and other things. Such composite characters are normally represented as ‚Äúgrapheme clusters‚Äù: runs of Unicode code points. The rules for handling these things can be quite complicated. But after many years of development, major operating systems now successfully do it in most cases. And in Version 13.1 we‚Äôre able to make use of this to support such constructs in notebooks.

A Toolbar for Every Notebook

It used to be that the only ‚Äúspecial key sequence‚Äù one absolutely should know in order to use Wolfram Notebooks was shiftenter. But gradually there have started to be more and more high-profile operations that are conveniently done by ‚Äúpressing a button‚Äù. And rather than expecting people to remember all those special key sequences (or think to look in menus for them) we‚Äôve decided to introduce a toolbar that will be displayed by default in every standard notebook. Polishing the User Interface


We first introduced Wolfram Notebooks with Version 1.0 of Mathematica, in 1988. And ever since then, we‚Äôve been progressively polishing the notebook interface, doing more with every new version.

What should the user interface for this be? It‚Äôs tricky, but I think we now have a good solution that we‚Äôve started deploying in Version 13.1.


In particular, in Version 13.1, there‚Äôs an example related to the Wolfram Function Repository. Say you use a function for which an update is available. Large-Scale Code Editing


One of the great things about the Wolfram Language is that it works well for programs of any scale‚Äîfrom less than a line long to millions of lines long.
